results.notes:
Growing on a hardwood chunk in the floodplain of Alum Creek. Not associated with an obvious subiculum. Not releasing a pigment in 1M KOH. Asci bitunicate, 8-spored and uniseriate. notes_fields.Habitat: Growing on a fallen oak log in oak-hickory forest.
notes_fields.Cap/upper_surface: Individual brackets up to 5-cm across, some fused; cream, velvety surface with thin concentric, brown, bald zones. They were rained on several times as they developed. On the first occasion, they turned a deep red-brown color with a cream margin so that they looked like Stereum ostrea. The colors reverted to the cream, velvety surfaces when they dried. The second time they were rained on, they tuned a more orange color with golden-yellow margin. The subsequent times they were rained on, they remained the same color as when they were dry.

results.notes:
Spores are globose, mainly 5-6.5 microns.
Spores seem large for C. applanatus. Cheilocystidia (pictured) seem to well-match what I have found online about those of C. applanatus. Spores are within the lower part of the range reported for C. malachius, but the cystidia seem different than what is reported for C. malachius.
Gills tapered/rounded near the point of attachment is a trait that seems to match better with C. malachius.

results.notes:
Two young flowering Phantom orchid(C. austiniae) beneath mature Douglas fir and Western red cedar found on the Priest point park main beach trail(approximately 100 yards from Budd inlet). Note the pointed flower tips, completely white(lacking chlorophyll-as with all Mycoheterotrophs) and bright yellow petal interior/throat. Plan to continue monitoring this location into next Fall and add images of any fruiting fungal associates that occur within 10ft for posterity/data(Thelephoraceae).
UPDATE on 6/7/29: Added growth images at full maturity. Also viewed and photographed 4 new flowering locations within a 50m transect I created on the SW facing hill at the Priest point beach entrance trail. Plan to monitor here through next Fall and hopefully photograph and collect a few fruiting bodies(Thelephoraceae members) for posterity to coincide with this observation. See added images from 6/7/19 in thumbnail bar.

Additional notes: Dozens in groups on a log. Caps under 2 inches, initially white, convex; becoming flatter, tan with white margin, then somewhat zoned with shades of tan and slight striation at the margin. Eventually deliquescing. Stipe is clear, translucent at the apex becoming cranberry red toward the base. Spore surface is latticed, bolete-like.
May be F. gracilis which has been reported for Mesoamerica, but coloring seems darker to me.

results.notes: Minute white fungus, in troops, on rotten deciduous wood, NO GILLS seen on specimen; stipe and edge of cap have pin-like protruding capitate cystidia (?), appearing to be of the same nature of fungus itself, which is glassy looking; wider at foot. Fungus is made of inflated hyphae; ‘pins’ have septa, and a rectangular foot for anchorage; see micro photos. Spores are elongated and pointy at one end with contents at ends, 8.9×2.5 m.u. Fungus is 4mm H, and cap 0.75 -1mm diameter.

results.notes:
Four new flowering locations observed/photographed on the Beach entrance trail at Priest Point park on 6/7/19 in Olympia, WA, USA. I began observing and monitoring at this location approximately one week prior of only a single collection/pair. All four flowering locations today are on a steep hill(facing SW) beneath a mature mother tree(Douglas fir 150+yr old at apex of steep hill). Multiple young and mature Thuja plicata in addition to the young P. menziesii beneath the massive mother at the top of hill. Multiple images of all 4 separate flowers added to this post(in addition to the mature mother tree and habitat). Will add images in Fall months(beginning in September) of possible fungal associate images and possibilities(Thelephoraceae members fruiting within my created 50m transect).
UPDATE ON 6/9/19: Found a new flowering location(6th total thus far) across the trail from the original sites that were just above the beach sands at Priest point park while walking with my son and wife. Yet again, this location was within about 50 feet of an uphill, massive Douglas fir that had the distinctive multilayered, fire proof bark of a 150+ year old tree(mother tree). Other trees between the mother and Phantom orchid flowering location were young Doug firs, Western red cedars and Madrone. I carefully harvested multiple seed pods and am mailed pollen samples to fellow naturalist Stewart Wechsler for him to hand pollinate one of the sections of his C. austiniae population at Lincoln park in Seattle, WA with my Priest point park collection pollen. As a continued study we will test and see how the introduced sections perform in seasons to come and may complete the same procedure(vise versa) here in sections of my transect if it is indeed successful with the Lincoln park lot next and following seasons. As mentioned previously, I will no doubt add a coinciding observation with herbarium collection of mycorrhizal species that occur within the transect in coming seasons(late the summer and onward). Stewart mentioned that he has had multiple Amanita species in his phantom orchid flowering vicinity(at the Lincoln park sites), but never successfully Thelephora(earth fans). Hopefully my transect will prove fruitful and we can have tangible evidence of fruiting mycorrhizal species to add to the greater knowledge and research regarding these beautiful mycoheterotrophic orchids and their sympathetic fungal partners-in association with mature Douglas firs, Western red cedar and vine maple. Multiple images/thumbnails added of the two new flowers on 6/9/19.
UPDATE 6/11/19: Mailed multiple harvested/dried samples of pollinia from this observation/collection to Stewart Wechsler for addition/pollination of his flowering C. austiniae populations at Lincoln park in Seattle, WA.

results.notes: Basidiomata gregariously fruiting on small vines of Campsis radicans (of the Bignoniaceae family), of which were growing around relatively large Pinus taeda trees, within a heavily shaded, wooded thicket (dominated by pine, sweet gum, tulip, cherry and a few very immature oaks), immediately following a rainy/humid period, overcast; Macro: Pleurotoid habit, basidiocarp small, delicate and partially fragile, Pileus ~ 10-20 mm broad, whitish to pale rosaceous or predominatly white with flushes of pink tones, especially towards margin, (generally whiter when young, developing the pink tones in age), very finely fibrillose (or at least appearing so when wet, or possibly with a finely roughened texture?), greasy to tacky, but not explicitly viscid by any means, faintly plicate or possibly lined from lamellae, somewhat rugulose, context scant, white and unchanging; Lamellae mostly well developed, white, very widely spaced and sometimes appearing variously forked, narrowly adnate to annexed, intervenose, 1-2 series lamellulae present of which appear somewhat venose and not well developed; Stipe laterally stipitate, mostly eccentric, 0.5 – 2.0 (2.5) mm long and up to 1 mm thick, appearing enlarged at stipe base (though could be basal mycelium?), white, densely fibrillose, thicker towards base (point of attachment to substrate); Odor/Taste nondistinctive, did not taste; Micro: Basidiospores elliptical/ellipsoid to limoniform, apiculate, frequently with a single large guttule (especially with immature spores), sometimes with multiple smaller guttules or appearing to contain small granule contents, ~ (9.6 – 10.3) 10.5 – 12.0 (12.8 – 13.5) x (4.5 – 5.5) 5.8 – 6.7 (6.8 – 7.3) μm; Q = 1.55 – 2.56; N = 67; (95% Conf: L x W = 11.0 – 11.4 × 6.2 – 6.4 μm; Q = 1.76 – 1.83); Basidia broadly cylindrical to narrowly clavate to clavate, with 4 sterigmata (sterigmata up to 3.5 – 4.0 μm long), ~ 27 – 34 × 8 – 10 μm, (L’ = 30.6 μm; W’ = 8.8 μm; Q’ = 3.5); Basidioles fusiform to fusoid to narrowly clavate, similar in size to basidia, a bit smaller; Cheilocystidia very common, versiform and irregular, lageniform to fusoid to clavate, frequently with diverticula (up to ~ 6 – 8 × 1 – 3 (4) μm), but also common without, sometimes with small and rounded apical mucro, ~ 15 – 25 (30) x 4 – 8 μm; Pleurocystidia not found; Lamellar trama regular, septate; Pileipellis a cutis, though some erect elements present, cylindrical with short and knobby diverticula scattered, hyaline and thin-walled, exhibiting some slight ornamentation, septate, sometimes constricted at septa, ~ 5 – 8 μm wide, some smaller cylindrical elements also present and containing yellowish/refractive elements in KOH; Pileal Trama consisting of interwoven, cylindrical hyphae, septate; Stipitipellis a cutis, hyphae resembling that of the pileipellis, elements both thin and thick-walled, exhibiting bands of ‘encrusted’ ornamentation; Caulocystidia not found, maybe absent or indistinguishable. Clamp Connections found in all hyphae/tissue, not present at every septa, but more or less occurring frequently.

results.notes:
Leratiomyces ceres (Agaricales, Strophariaceae) Bogotá, Colombia
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/40641362
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/50875899

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

Basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, el Píleo mide entre 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse hacia el borde, con escamas fasciculadas originadas por restos del velo universal que forma un círculo a modo de collar cerca del borde. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, pruinoso. Se engrosa ligeramente hacia la base. De consistencia fibrosa. Sin olor o sabor apreciable. Basidiosporas elipsoidales, lisas, de paredes gruesas, con poro germinal.

Primer registro de esta especie para Colombia. Segun Vasco-Palacios AM, Franco-Molano AE. 2013, la familia Strophariaceae esta representada por las siguientes especies:

Hypholoma sublateritium (Schaeff.) Quél.
Hypholoma subviride (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Dennis.
Melanotus alpiniae (Berk.) Pilát.
Melanotus cassiaecolor (Berk.) Singer.
Melanotus dumontii Singer
Naematoloma subviride (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) A.H.
Naematoloma udum (Pers.) P. Karst..
Pholiota aberrans A.H.
Pholiota apiahyna Speg.
Pholiota naucorioides Singer.
Pholiota privigna (Speg.) Singer.
Pleuroflammula squarrulosa Singer.
Psilocybe angustipleurocystidiata Guzmán.
Psilocybe antioquiensis Guzmán, Saldarr., Pineda, G. García & L.-F. Velázquez.

results.notes:
A solitary specimen in suburban residential lawn. Nearest tree associates 30’ away and include Oak, Maple, Sweet Gum, and Redbud. Boletes remain my nemesis, and while trying to key this one out and using some other resources I found contradictions galore when I narrowed the ID down to either T. badius or T. ferrugineus. Of course, I may not be correct with either identification; however, at this point I am leaning toward the latter based on the suburban, rather than woodland, habitat. Cap (measured across the top) 12 cm., small in-rolled sterile margin. Stipe: 7 cm. X 2.5 cm. (see image #1340), purplish net reticulation on stipe and some white reticulation at the apex, white mycelium at base. Tubes: 6 mm. Pores: angular, 2/mm. Pore surface: originally white, gradually developing pinkish-tan overtones, bruising light brown. Chemical reactions can be seen in collage images. Spore print pending.

The beautiful in situ photograph was taken by Kim Martin who collected this specimen for me.

results.notes:
Found growing singly, terrestrially a few feet from the chicken coop in my backyard. No rotting wood nearby. Soil is bare and consistently tread upon by chickens. No color change when I bruised the cap margin, nor when I bruised the the stem base.

I think this mushroom is Agaricus campestris, but Michael Kuo states in his book that they appear in late summer through early winter.

I’m planning to take a tissue culture, bulk up into spawn and inoculate some compost for fun.

results.notes:
It is only elm with X. poeltii like lichen with apothecia (very rare, 1:300). This lichen has a more dissected and more branching leaves than other similar xanthomendoza. Apothecia size is 0.3-1mm.
X. poeltii is mainly without of rhizines and apothecia are very rare (according Oxner).
Sometimes we cannot see rhizines of X. webery (Oxner’s note).
C+ as pink vine up to purple, K+ deep purple up to dark purple-brown.

results.notes: Fruiting from a cankered limb of Pinus resinosa. Ascoma hard and erumpent, after two days of incubation they opened up becoming fleshy and cupulate, measuring 3-5 mm in diameter when opened. Asci 8-spored, unitunicate, inoperculate, inamyloid. Paraphyses filamentous, septate, slightly inflated at tips. Medullary excipulum interwoven hyphae, ectal excipulum looks globose with pigmented brown walls. Spores hyaline, ellipsoid, and smooth. Ascospores measured from ejected spores in H20 ~9.2 × 6 um.

Growing on decaying, often suspended herbaceous material (tropical kudzu, banana pseudostem fibers) as well as at least one woody stick. Growing near creekbed shaded by banana plants near urbanized portion of secondary humid forest, appearing after the onset of rains during rainy season. Brittle, waxy ascocarps, in some cases covering the substrate in a waxy layer. Fruiting body including context generally concolorous. Odor spermatic.

results.notes: A quad fruiting under shrubbery in suburban residence. Tree associates oak and birch. Most mature cap: 6.5 cm. Stipe: 5 cm. X 1.5 cm. at apex and 1 cm. at base. Tubes: 1 cm. Pore surface bruises blue then black. Flesh and tubes bruise blue when sliced. Obtained only a scant olive-brown spore print, probably because it rained heavily the night before collection. See chemical reactions in images # 0858, 0850A, 0851, 0863.
results.location_name: West St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes: A solitary specimen fruiting on the wood of a well rotted log in oak-hickory woods. Obtained a salmon-pink spore print.
results.location_name: Bootlegger's Run Trail, Creve Coeur Lake Memorial Park, Maryland Heights, Missouri, USA

results.notes: Several specimens clustered in grass under oak, birch and a conifer; residential landscape. Largest cap: 5.8 cm., lined margin. Stipe: 3.5 cm. X 1.7 cm., flesh chalk white, unchanging when sliced, crumbly, cavernous. KOH yellow on cap. Creamy spore print.
results.location_name: West St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes: Fruiting from the side of a decaying stump on residential property, causing a white rot. Specimen tough, very pliable; non-fertile surface is covered in fine hairs; 4 mm. thick at rim. Some pores are round and some angular. 2 pores/mm. KOH fleetingly pale yellow on cap surface and context.
results.location_name: West St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes: Found these two isolated LBM’s adjacent to the footpath through my deciduous 1/2 acre woodlot among ash tree mulch from last season. Kept returning to the same site for about three weeks now and haven’t found any more. Help!

results.notes: Growing on the underside of a hardwood log, likely from an Acer sp. Tomentum white to rusty brown. All structures inamyloid. Paraphyses filiform. Spore measurements: (37.7) 39.9 – 47.5 (56.9) × (4.9) 5.1 – 6 (6.7) µm, Q = (6.1) 7.2 – 8.6 (10.2); N = 30, Me = 43.9 × 5.6 µm; Qe = 7.9

results.notes:
On a fallen birch branch.
Spores 8-10 × 2.9-3.1. This range favors leptocephalus over varius (according to C du Q).
results.location_name: Sweet Valley, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Growing at the mossy base of a rotting Scotch pine stump.
Squeezed out a tiny bi of liquid, but it wasn’t red.
Gills with slightly pigmented edges along the marginal 30-40% of the length.
Odor indistinct.
Cap margins without prominent “flaps”.
Cheilocystidia numerous, variable in shape. Some with uniformly thickened midsection and variably long apical projection with pointed tip. Some seen projecting from the gill edge as cylinders capped by a conical/acute tip that appears to be ornamented. Some with a more general fusoid ventricose shape.
Spores 10-12(12.5) x 5.5-7, ellipsoid.
results.location_name: Sweet Valley, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes: (In the photo, the color appears too green, but in reality is more brown dirty up close). On the underside of rotten wood; f.b. fully resupinate, forming a patch of soft cottony texture, darker inside, no particular margin. No cystidia seen. KOH turned it dark brown.
results.location_name: Historic Smithville Park, Eastampton Twp., Burlington Co., New Jersey, USA

results.notes: Grew in mulched garden bed, soil amended with organic compost that contained manure. Very slimy. Many in a small area, next to Sedum.
results.location_name: Kingsley, Michigan, USA

results.notes:
Solitary, on the ground in area riddled with sticks, leaves, and hickory nut husks.
Spores variably shaped as a function of perspective; elliptical, sublacrymoid, a few shaped like a parallelogram with rounded corners. Mounted in Congo red the surfaces appeared to be minutely punctate (not visible in photo). But, as far as I know, Gymnopus spores are smooth. 7-12 × 4-5.
Cheilocystidia cylindrical.
Last two photos show objects that look like cystidia (ventricose with rounded ends); see last two photos). These were attached to the part of the gill that I cut. Maybe just unusually-shaped hyphae?
results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA
